content:
I’m Danielle “Dani” Barquinero, a PhD student at the University of Iowa studying Topology. This website hosts my papers, talks, and other academic resources as well as contact information.
If you are a student looking for course information, see the teaching tab.

content:
Summary Functions, relations, coordinate systems; properties and graphs of algebraic, trigonometric, logarithmic, exponential functions; inverse trigonometric functions; properties of lines, conic sections.
Course Information Meeting times: M/W/F 3:30 - 4:20 PM in 22 SH, Tu 3:30 - 4:20 PM in 117 MLH Office hour: 4:30-5:20 PM and by appointment in 225C MLH Course Website Course listing Course supervisor: Olga Sokratova Taught During Fall 2023
summary: College Algebra and Precalculus
title: MATH:1020:0331 Elementary Functions

content:
Summary Fundamental concepts, limits, methods, and techniques of differential calculus of a single variable; definite and indefinite integrals, substitution rule, fundamental theorem of calculus; applications including graphing, extreme values, areas, and volumes.
Course Information Meeting times: M/T/W/F 3:30 - 4:20 PM in 61 SH Office hour: T 12:30 - 1:30 PM, Th 3:30 - 4:30 PM, and by appointment in 225C MLH Course Website Course listing Course supervisor: Xiaoyi Zhang Taught from Stewart James; Clegg Daniel K.; Watson Saleem: Single Variable Calculus: Early Transcendentals, ISBN: 9780357022269. Taught During Spring 2023
summary: Calculus I
title: MATH:1850:0431 Calculus I

content:
Summary Functions, relations, coordinate systems; properties and graphs of algebraic, trigonometric, logarithmic, exponential functions; inverse trigonometric functions; properties of lines, conic sections.
Course Information Meeting times: T/Th 6:30 - 8:20 PM in 113 MLH Office hour: Tuesdays 5 - 6PM and by appointment in 226C MLH Course Website Course listing Course supervisor: Olga Sokratova Taught During Fall 2022
summary: College Algebra and Precalculus
title: MATH:1020:0631 Elementary Functions

content:
Summary Relations, functions, coordinate systems, graphing, polynomials, trigonometric functions, logarithmic and exponential functions; discrete mathematics, probability; examples and applications from biological sciences.
Course Information Spring 2022, Section 0A05
Meeting times (Lecture): M/W/F 10:30 - 11:20 AM on Zoom (see syllabus for link) Meeting times (Discussion): T/Th 3:30 - 4:20 PM in 217 MLH Office hour (Instructor): M/W 1:00 - 2:00 PM, F 2:00 - 3:00 PM on Zoom Office hour (TA): Thursdays 12:55 - 1:55 PM and by appointment in MB 261 Course Website (Main) Course Website (Discussion) Course listing Course supervisor: Victor Camillo Fall 2021, Section 0A02
Meeting times (Lecture): T/Th 8:00 - 9:15 AM on Zoom (see syllabus for link) Meeting times (Discussion): W/F 7:30 - 8:20 AM in 105 MLH Office hour (Instructor): M/W 1:00 - 2:00 PM, F 2:00 - 3:00 PM on Zoom Office hour (TA): Wednesdays 8:45 - 9:45 AM and by appointment in MB 261 Course Website (Main) Course Website (Discussion) Course listing Course supervisor: Victor Camillo Taught During Fall 2021 Spring 2022
summary: Precalculus and probability for biology majors
title: MATH:1440 Mathematics for the Biological Sciences

content:
Summary One-semester survey of calculus for students in biological or life sciences; nontheoretical treatment of differential and integral calculus; brief introduction to differential equations and probability with calculus, with applications to the life sciences.
Course Information Meeting times (Lecture A): M/W/F 1:30 - 2:20 PM on Zoom (see syllabus for link) Meeting times (Lecture B): M/W/F 2:30 - 3:20 PM on Zoom (see syllabus for link) Meeting times (Discussion): T/Th 5:00 - 5:50 PM in 218 MLH Office hour (Instructor): Tuesdays 9:00 - 11:30 AM and by appointment on Zoom Office hour (TA): Mondays 12:45 - 1:45 PM and by appointment in MB 261 Course Website (Main A) Course Website (Main B) Course Website (Discussion) Course listing Course supervisor: Xiaoyi Zhang Taught During Fall 2021
summary: Calculus with a focus for applications in biology programs
title: MATH:1460:0432 Calculus for the Biological Sciences

summary: A five day long conference focusing on spaces of diffeomorphisms, symplectomorphisms, and contactomorphisms in dimensions three and four.
title: 2023 Georgia Topology Conference

summary: A week long summer school in Budapest focusing on knot theory, lattice cohomology, curve singularities, and Heegaard-Floer homology.
title: Winter School in Singularities and Low Dimensional Topology

summary: Following *Foundations of Hyperbolic Manifolds* by John Ratcliffe. A series of three talks presented together with another member of the UI Topology/Geometry RTG, Nicholas Cecil, over the course of three consecutive weeks.
title: Mostow's Rigidity Theorem

summary: Following Chapter 8 of *A Primer in Mapping Class Groups* by Farb and Margalit. Proof of Dehn-Nielsen-Baer Theorem and Milnor-Svarc Lemma and all required definitions therein.
title: Dehn-Nielsen-Baer Theorem and Milnor-Svarc Lemma

summary: An eleven day workshop in Madrid on topics relating to geometric group theory and low dimensional topology.
title: Graduate school on Geometric Group Theory and Low Dimensional Topology

summary: Following Chapter 1 of *An Introduction to Homological Algebra* by Weibel. Definitions, homotopy of chain complexes, homology.
title: Chain complexes and homology

summary: Computation of some mapping class groups and proof of Alexander's Method.
title: Alexander's Method

summary: We study Artin kernels and we show that they decompose as graphs of groups in a way that can be explicitly computed from the underlying graph.
title: Graphical splittings of Artin kernels

summary: [Postponed due to COVID]
title: Eastern Illinois Integrated Conference in Geometry, Dynamics, and Topology 2020

summary: A poster board presentation where participants present the work they completed throughout the year in the Undergraduate Research Opportunity Program. Presented our work on Artin Kernels, see Papers tab.
title: Florida State University - UROP Symposium
